info.description:
Amazon Cloud Directory

Amazon Cloud Directory is a component of the AWS Directory Service that simplifies the development and management of cloud-scale web, mobile, and IoT applications. This guide describes the Cloud Directory operations that you can call programmatically and includes detailed information on data types and errors. For information about Cloud Directory features, see AWS Directory Service and the Amazon Cloud Directory Developer Guide.
info.title: Amazon CloudDirectory

post.description: Performs all the read operations in a batch.

Responses.description: A list of all the responses for each batch read.

items.description: Represents the output of a BatchRead response operation.

ExceptionResponse.description: Identifies which operation in a batch has failed.

Message.description: An exception message that is associated with the failure.

Type.description: A type of exception, such as InvalidArnException.

SuccessfulResponse.description: Identifies which operation in a batch has succeeded.

GetLinkAttributes.description: The list of attributes to retrieve from the typed link.

Attributes.description: The attributes that are associated with the typed link.

items.description: The combination of an attribute key and an attribute value.

FacetName.description: The name of the facet that the attribute exists within.

SchemaArn.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the schema that contains the facet and attribute.

Value.description: The value of the attribute.

GetObjectAttributes.description: Retrieves attributes within a facet that are associated with an object.

Attributes.description: The attribute values that are associated with an object.

items.description: The combination of an attribute key and an attribute value.

FacetName.description: The name of the facet that the attribute exists within.

SchemaArn.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the schema that contains the facet and attribute.

Value.description: The value of the attribute.

ObjectIdentifier.description: The ObjectIdentifier of the specified object.

SchemaFacets.description: The facets attached to the specified object.

items.description: A facet.

FacetName.description: The name of the facet.

SchemaArn.description: The ARN of the schema that contains the facet with no minor component. See arns and In-Place Schema Upgrade for a description of when to provide minor versions.

ListAttachedIndices.description: Lists indices attached to an object.

IndexAttachments.description: The indices attached to the specified object.

items.description: Represents an index and an attached object.
The combination of an attribute key and an attribute value.

FacetName.description: The name of the facet that the attribute exists within.

SchemaArn.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the schema that contains the facet and attribute.

Value.description: The value of the attribute.

ObjectIdentifier.description: In response to ListIndex, the ObjectIdentifier of the object attached to the index. In response to ListAttachedIndices, the ObjectIdentifier of the index attached to the object. This field will always contain the ObjectIdentifier of the object on the opposite side of the attachment specified in the query.

ListIncomingTypedLinks.description: Returns a paginated list of all the incoming TypedLinkSpecifier information for an object. It also supports filtering by typed link facet and identity attributes. For more information, see Typed Links.

LinkSpecifiers.description: Returns one or more typed link specifiers as output.

items.description: Contains all the information that is used to uniquely identify a typed link. The parameters discussed in this topic are used to uniquely specify the typed link being operated on. The AttachTypedLink API returns a typed link specifier while the DetachTypedLink API accepts one as input. Similarly, the ListIncomingTypedLinks and ListOutgoingTypedLinks API operations provide typed link specifiers as output. You can also construct a typed link specifier from scratch.

IdentityAttributeValues.description: Identifies the attribute value to update.

items.description: Identifies the attribute name and value for a typed link.

AttributeName.description: The attribute name of the typed link.

Value.description: The value for the typed link.

SourceObjectReference.description: Identifies the source object that the typed link will attach to.

Selector.description:
A path selector supports easy selection of an object by the parent/child links leading to it from the directory root. Use the link names from each parent/child link to construct the path. Path selectors start with a slash (/) and link names are separated by slashes. For more information about paths, see Access Objects. You can identify an object in one of the following ways:

  • $ObjectIdentifier - An object identifier is an opaque string provided by Amazon Cloud Directory. When creating objects, the system will provide you with the identifier of the created object. An object’s identifier is immutable and no two objects will ever share the same object identifier

  • /some/path - Identifies the object based on path

  • #SomeBatchReference - Identifies the object in a batch call

TargetObjectReference.description: Identifies the target object that the typed link will attach to.

SchemaArn.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that is associated with the schema. For more information, see arns.

TypedLinkName.description: The unique name of the typed link facet.

IndexAttachments.description: The objects and indexed values attached to the index.

items.description: Represents an index and an attached object.
The combination of an attribute key and an attribute value.

ObjectIdentifier.description: In response to ListIndex, the ObjectIdentifier of the object attached to the index. This field will always contain the ObjectIdentifier of the object on the opposite side of the attachment specified in the query.

Children.description: The children structure, which is a map with the key as the LinkName and ObjectIdentifier as the value.

ListObjectParentPaths.description: Retrieves all available parent paths for any object type such as node, leaf node, policy node, and index node objects. For more information about objects, see Directory Structure.

PathToObjectIdentifiersList.description: Returns the path to the ObjectIdentifiers that are associated with the directory.

items.description: Returns the path to the ObjectIdentifiers that is associated with the directory.

ObjectIdentifiers.description: Lists ObjectIdentifiers starting from directory root to the object in the request.

Path.description: The path that is used to identify the object starting from directory root.

items.description: A pair of ObjectIdentifier and LinkName.

LinkName.description: The name of the link between the parent and the child object.

ObjectIdentifier.description: The ID that is associated with the object.

ListObjectPolicies.description: Returns policies attached to an object in pagination fashion.

AttachedPolicyIds.description: A list of policy ObjectIdentifiers, that are attached to the object.

ListOutgoingTypedLinks.description: Returns a paginated list of all the outgoing TypedLinkSpecifier information for an object. It also supports filtering by typed link facet and identity attributes. For more information, see Typed Links.

ListPolicyAttachments.description: Returns all of the ObjectIdentifiers to which a given policy is attached.

ObjectIdentifiers.description: A list of ObjectIdentifiers to which the policy is attached.

LookupPolicy.description: Lists all policies from the root of the Directory to the object specified. If there are no policies present, an empty list is returned. If policies are present, and if some objects don't have the policies attached, it returns the ObjectIdentifier for such objects. If policies are present, it returns ObjectIdentifier, policyId, and policyType. Paths that don't lead to the root from the target object are ignored. For more information, see Policies.

PolicyToPathList.description: Provides list of path to policies. Policies contain PolicyId, ObjectIdentifier, and PolicyType. For more information, see Policies.

items.description: Used when a regular object exists in a Directory and you want to find all of the policies that are associated with that object and the parent to that object.

Path.description: The path that is referenced from the root.

items.description: Contains the PolicyType, PolicyId, and the ObjectIdentifier to which it is attached. For more information, see Policies.

ObjectIdentifier.description: The ObjectIdentifier that is associated with PolicyAttachment.

PolicyType.description: The type of policy that can be associated with PolicyAttachment.

Operations.description: A list of operations that are part of the batch.

items.description: Represents the output of a BatchRead operation.

Selector.description:
A path selector supports easy selection of an object by the parent/child links leading to it from the directory root. Use the link names from each parent/child link to construct the path. Path selectors start with a slash (/) and link names are separated by slashes. For more information about paths, see Access Objects. You can identify an object in one of the following ways:

  • $ObjectIdentifier - An object identifier is an opaque string provided by Amazon Cloud Directory. When creating objects, the system will provide you with the identifier of the created object. An object’s identifier is immutable and no two objects will ever share the same object identifier

  • /some/path - Identifies the object based on path

  • #SomeBatchReference - Identifies the object in a batch call

TypedLinkFacet.description: Identifies the typed link facet that is associated with the typed link.

SchemaArn.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that is associated with the schema. For more information, see arns.

TypedLinkName.description: The unique name of the typed link facet.

CreateIndex.description: Creates an index object. See Indexing and search for more information.

ObjectIdentifier.description: The ObjectIdentifier of the index created by this operation.
The ID that is associated with the object.

DetachFromIndex.description: Detaches the specified object from the specified index.

DetachedObjectIdentifier.description: The ObjectIdentifier of the object that was detached from the index.

DetachTypedLink.description: Detaches a typed link from a specified source and target object. For more information, see Typed Links.

RemoveFacetFromObject.description: The result of a batch remove facet from object operation.

UpdateLinkAttributes.description: Represents the output of a BatchWrite response operation.

ObjectIdentifier.description: ID that is associated with the object.

Operations.description: A list of operations that are part of the batch.

items.description: Represents the output of a BatchWrite operation.

AddFacetToObject.description: A batch operation that adds a facet to an object.

ObjectAttributeList.description: The attributes to set on the object.

items.description: The combination of an attribute key and an attribute value.

FacetName.description: The name of the facet that the attribute exists within.

SchemaArn.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the schema that contains the facet and attribute.

Value.description: The value of the attribute.

ObjectReference.description: A reference to the object being mutated.

put.description: Deletes a directory. Only disabled directories can be deleted. A deleted directory cannot be undone. Exercise extreme caution when deleting directories.

DirectoryArn.description: The ARN of the deleted directory.

put.description:
Creates a Directory by copying the published schema into the directory. A directory cannot be created without a schema.

You can also quickly create a directory using a managed schema, called the QuickStartSchema. For more information, see Managed Schema in the Amazon Cloud Directory Developer Guide.

AppliedSchemaArn.description: The ARN of the published schema in the Directory. Once a published schema is copied into the directory, it has its own ARN, which is referred to applied schema ARN. For more information, see arns.

DirectoryArn.description: The ARN that is associated with the Directory. For more information, see arns.

ObjectIdentifier.description: The root object node of the created directory.

Name.description: The name of the Directory. Should be unique per account, per region.

put.description: Disables the specified directory. Disabled directories cannot be read or written to. Only enabled directories can be disabled. Disabled directories may be reenabled.

DirectoryArn.description: The ARN of the directory that has been disabled.

put.description: Enables the specified directory. Only disabled directories can be enabled. Once enabled, the directory can then be read and written to.

DirectoryArn.description: The ARN of the enabled directory.

post.description: Retrieves metadata about a directory.

CreationDateTime.description: The date and time when the directory was created.

DirectoryArn.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that is associated with the directory. For more information, see arns.

State.description: The state of the directory. Can be either Enabled, Disabled, or Deleted.

post.description: Lists directories created within an account.

Directories.description: Lists all directories that are associated with your account in pagination fashion.

items.description: Directory structure that includes the directory name and directory ARN.

CreationDateTime.description: The date and time when the directory was created.

DirectoryArn.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that is associated with the directory. For more information, see arns.

State.description: The state of the directory. Can be either Enabled, Disabled, or Deleted.

MaxResults.description: The maximum number of results to retrieve.

state.description: The state of the directories in the list. Can be either Enabled, Disabled, or Deleted.

post.description: Gets details of the Facet, such as facet name, attributes, Rules, or ObjectType. You can call this on all kinds of schema facets -- published, development, or applied.

Facet.description: The Facet structure that is associated with the facet.

FacetStyle.description: There are two different styles that you can define on any given facet, Static and Dynamic. For static facets, all attributes must be defined in the schema. For dynamic facets, attributes can be defined during data plane operations.

ObjectType.description: The object type that is associated with the facet. See CreateFacetRequest$ObjectType for more details.

Name.description: The name of the facet to retrieve.

put.description:
Does the following:

  1. Adds new Attributes, Rules, or ObjectTypes.

  2. Updates existing Attributes, Rules, or ObjectTypes.

  3. Deletes existing Attributes, Rules, or ObjectTypes.

AttributeUpdates.description: List of attributes that need to be updated in a given schema Facet. Each attribute is followed by AttributeAction, which specifies the type of update operation to perform.

items.description: A structure that contains information used to update an attribute.

Action.description: The action to perform when updating the attribute.

AttributeDefinition.description: A facet attribute consists of either a definition or a reference. This structure contains the attribute definition. See Attribute References for more information.

DefaultValue.description: The default value of the attribute (if configured).

IsImmutable.description: Whether the attribute is mutable or not.

Rules.description: Validation rules attached to the attribute definition.

value.description: Contains an Amazon Resource Name (ARN) and parameters that are associated with the rule.

Parameters.description: The minimum and maximum parameters that are associated with the rule.

Type.description: The type of attribute validation rule.
The type of the attribute.

AttributeReference.description: An attribute reference that is associated with the attribute. See Attribute References for more information.

TargetAttributeName.description: The target attribute name that is associated with the facet reference. See Attribute References for more information.

TargetFacetName.description: The target facet name that is associated with the facet reference. See Attribute References for more information.

Name.description: The name of the facet attribute.

ObjectType.description: The object type that is associated with the facet. See CreateFacetRequest$ObjectType for more details.

post.description: Retrieves attributes attached to the facet.

Attributes.description: The attributes attached to the facet.

items.description: An attribute that is associated with the Facet.

AttributeDefinition.description: A facet attribute consists of either a definition or a reference. This structure contains the attribute definition. See Attribute References for more information.

DefaultValue.description: The default value of the attribute (if configured).

IsImmutable.description: Whether the attribute is mutable or not.

Rules.description: Validation rules attached to the attribute definition.

value.description: Contains an Amazon Resource Name (ARN) and parameters that are associated with the rule.

Parameters.description: The minimum and maximum parameters that are associated with the rule.

Type.description: The type of attribute validation rule.

Name.description: The name of the facet attribute.

MaxResults.description: The maximum number of results to retrieve.

Name.description: The name of the facet whose attributes will be retrieved.

put.description: Creates a new Facet in a schema. Facet creation is allowed only in development or applied schemas.

Attributes.description: The attributes that are associated with the Facet.

items.description: An attribute that is associated with the Facet.

FacetStyle.description: There are two different styles that you can define on any given facet, Static and Dynamic. For static facets, all attributes must be defined in the schema. For dynamic facets, attributes can be defined during data plane operations.

Name.description: The name of the Facet, which is unique for a given schema.

ObjectType.description:
Specifies whether a given object created from this facet is of type node, leaf node, policy or index.

  • Node: Can have multiple children but one parent.

  • Leaf node: Cannot have children but can have multiple parents.

  • Policy: Allows you to store a policy document and policy type. For more information, see Policies.

  • Index: Can be created with the Index API.

put.description: Deletes a given Facet. All attributes and Rules that are associated with the facet will be deleted. Only development schema facets are allowed deletion.

post.description: Retrieves the names of facets that exist in a schema.

Selector.description:
A path selector supports easy selection of an object by the parent/child links leading to it from the directory root. Use the link names from each parent/child link to construct the path. Path selectors start with a slash (/) and link names are separated by slashes. For more information about paths, see Access Objects. You can identify an object in one of the following ways:

  • $ObjectIdentifier - An object identifier is an opaque string provided by Amazon Cloud Directory. When creating objects, the system will provide you with the identifier of the created object. An object’s identifier is immutable and no two objects will ever share the same object identifier

  • /some/path - Identifies the object based on path

  • #SomeBatchReference - Identifies the object in a batch call

post.description:
Retrieves all available parent paths for any object type such as node, leaf node, policy node, and index node objects. For more information about objects, see Directory Structure.

Use this API to evaluate all parents for an object. The call returns all objects from the root of the directory up to the requested object. The API returns the number of paths based on user-defined MaxResults, in case there are multiple paths to the parent. The order of the paths and nodes returned is consistent among multiple API calls unless the objects are deleted or moved. Paths not leading to the directory root are ignored from the target object.

A path selector supports easy selection of an object by the parent/child links leading to it from the directory root. Use the link names from each parent/child link to construct the path. Path selectors start with a slash (/) and link names are separated by slashes. For more information about paths, see Access Objects. You can identify an object in one of the following ways:

  • $ObjectIdentifier - An object identifier is an opaque string provided by Amazon Cloud Directory. When creating objects, the system will provide you with the identifier of the created object. An object’s identifier is immutable and no two objects will ever share the same object identifier

  • /some/path - Identifies the object based on path

  • #SomeBatchReference - Identifies the object in a batch call

put.description: Detaches a policy from an object.

ObjectReference.description: Reference that identifies the object whose policy object will be detached.

post.description: Lists all policies from the root of the Directory to the object specified. If there are no policies present, an empty list is returned. If policies are present, and if some objects don't have the policies attached, it returns the ObjectIdentifier for such objects. If policies are present, it returns ObjectIdentifier, policyId, and policyType. Paths that don't lead to the root from the target object are ignored. For more information, see Policies.

PolicyToPathList.description: Provides list of path to policies. Policies contain PolicyId, ObjectIdentifier, and PolicyType. For more information, see Policies.

items.description: Used when a regular object exists in a Directory and you want to find all of the policies that are associated with that object and the parent to that object.

Path.description: The path that is referenced from the root.

items.description: Contains the PolicyType, PolicyId, and the ObjectIdentifier to which it is attached. For more information, see Policies.

ObjectIdentifier.description: The ObjectIdentifier that is associated with PolicyAttachment.

PolicyType.description: The type of policy that can be associated with PolicyAttachment.

MaxResults.description: The maximum number of items to be retrieved in a single call. This is an approximate number.

NextToken.description: The token to request the next page of results.

ObjectReference.description: Reference that identifies the object whose policies will be looked up.

put.description: Deletes a given schema. Schemas in a development and published state can only be deleted.

SchemaArn.description: The input ARN that is returned as part of the response. For more information, see arns.

post.description: Lists schema major versions applied to a directory. If SchemaArn is provided, lists the minor version.

SchemaArns.description: The ARNs of schemas that are applied to the directory.

DirectoryArn.description: The ARN of the directory you are listing.

MaxResults.description: The maximum number of results to retrieve.

SchemaArn.description: The response for ListAppliedSchemaArns when this parameter is used will list all minor version ARNs for a major version.

put.description: Copies the input published schema, at the specified version, into the Directory with the same name and version as that of the published schema.

AppliedSchemaArn.description: The applied schema ARN that is associated with the copied schema in the Directory. You can use this ARN to describe the schema information applied on this directory. For more information, see arns.

DirectoryArn.description: The ARN that is associated with the Directory. For more information, see arns.

PublishedSchemaArn.description: Published schema Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that needs to be copied. For more information, see arns.

put.description:
Creates a new schema in a development state. A schema can exist in three phases:

  • Development: This is a mutable phase of the schema. All new schemas are in the development phase. Once the schema is finalized, it can be published.

  • Published: Published schemas are immutable and have a version associated with them.

  • Applied: Applied schemas are mutable in a way that allows you to add new schema facets. You can also add new, nonrequired attributes to existing schema facets. You can apply only published schemas to directories.

SchemaArn.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that is associated with the schema. For more information, see arns.

Name.description: The name that is associated with the schema. This is unique to each account and in each region.

post.description: Retrieves each Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of schemas in the development state.

SchemaArns.description: The ARNs of retrieved development schemas.

MaxResults.description: The maximum number of results to retrieve.

post.description: Returns current applied schema version ARN, including the minor version in use.

AppliedSchemaArn.description: Current applied schema ARN, including the minor version in use if one was provided.

SchemaArn.description: The ARN of the applied schema.

post.description: Retrieves a JSON representation of the schema. See JSON Schema Format for more information.

Document.description: The JSON representation of the schema document.

Name.description: The name of the retrieved schema.

put.description: Allows a schema to be updated using JSON upload. Only available for development schemas. See JSON Schema Format for more information.

Arn.description: The ARN of the schema to update.

post.description: Lists the major version families of each managed schema. If a major version ARN is provided as SchemaArn, the minor version revisions in that family are listed instead.

SchemaArns.description: The ARNs for all AWS managed schemas.

MaxResults.description: The maximum number of results to retrieve.

SchemaArn.description: The response for ListManagedSchemaArns. When this parameter is used, all minor version ARNs for a major version are listed.

put.description: Publishes a development schema with a major version and a recommended minor version.

PublishedSchemaArn.description: The ARN that is associated with the published schema. For more information, see arns.

MinorVersion.description: The minor version under which the schema will be published. This parameter is recommended. Schemas have both a major and minor version associated with them.

Name.description: The new name under which the schema will be published. If this is not provided, the development schema is considered.

Version.description: The major version under which the schema will be published. Schemas have both a major and minor version associated with them.

post.description: Lists the major version families of each published schema. If a major version ARN is provided as SchemaArn, the minor version revisions in that family are listed instead.

MaxResults.description: The maximum number of results to retrieve.

SchemaArn.description: The response for ListPublishedSchemaArns when this parameter is used will list all minor version ARNs for a major version.

put.description: Updates the schema name with a new name. Only development schema names can be updated.

SchemaArn.description: The ARN that is associated with the updated schema. For more information, see arns.

put.description: Upgrades a single directory in-place using the PublishedSchemaArn with schema updates found in MinorVersion. Backwards-compatible minor version upgrades are instantaneously available for readers on all objects in the directory. Note: This is a synchronous API call and upgrades only one schema on a given directory per call. To upgrade multiple directories from one schema, you would need to call this API on each directory.

DirectoryArn.description: The ARN of the directory that is returned as part of the response.

UpgradedSchemaArn.description: The ARN of the upgraded schema that is returned as part of the response.

DirectoryArn.description: The ARN for the directory to which the upgraded schema will be applied.

DryRun.description: Used for testing whether the major version schemas are backward compatible or not. If schema compatibility fails, an exception would be thrown else the call would succeed but no changes will be saved. This parameter is optional.

PublishedSchemaArn.description: The revision of the published schema to upgrade the directory to.

put.description: Upgrades a published schema under a new minor version revision using the current contents of DevelopmentSchemaArn.

UpgradedSchemaArn.description: The ARN of the upgraded schema that is returned as part of the response.

DevelopmentSchemaArn.description: The ARN of the development schema with the changes used for the upgrade.

DryRun.description: Used for testing whether the Development schema provided is backwards compatible, or not, with the publish schema provided by the user to be upgraded. If schema compatibility fails, an exception would be thrown else the call would succeed. This parameter is optional and defaults to false.

MinorVersion.description: Identifies the minor version of the published schema that will be created. This parameter is NOT optional.

PublishedSchemaArn.description: The ARN of the published schema to be upgraded.

post.description: Returns tags for a resource. Tagging is currently supported only for directories with a limit of 50 tags per directory. All 50 tags are returned for a given directory with this API call.

NextToken.description: The token to use to retrieve the next page of results. This value is null when there are no more results to return.

Tags.description: A list of tag key value pairs that are associated with the response.

items.description: The tag structure that contains a tag key and value.

Key.description: The key that is associated with the tag.

Value.description: The value that is associated with the tag.

MaxResults.description: The MaxResults parameter sets the maximum number of results returned in a single page. This is for future use and is not supported currently.

NextToken.description: The pagination token. This is for future use. Currently pagination is not supported for tagging.

ResourceArn.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource. Tagging is only supported for directories.

put.description: An API operation for adding tags to a resource.

ResourceArn.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource. Tagging is only supported for directories.

Tags.description: A list of tag key-value pairs.

items.description: The tag structure that contains a tag key and value.

Key.description: The key that is associated with the tag.

Value.description: The value that is associated with the tag.

put.description: An API operation for removing tags from a resource.

ResourceArn.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource. Tagging is only supported for directories.

TagKeys.description: Keys of the tag that need to be removed from the resource.

The type of the attribute.

IdentityAttributeOrder.description: The order of identity attributes for the facet, from most significant to least significant. The ability to filter typed links considers the order that the attributes are defined on the typed link facet. When providing ranges to a typed link selection, any inexact ranges must be specified at the end. Any attributes that do not have a range specified are presumed to match the entire range. Filters are interpreted in the order of the attributes on the typed link facet, not the order in which they are supplied to any API calls. For more information about identity attributes, see Typed Links.

Selector.description:
A path selector supports easy selection of an object by the parent/child links leading to it from the directory root. Use the link names from each parent/child link to construct the path. Path selectors start with a slash (/) and link names are separated by slashes. For more information about paths, see Access Objects. You can identify an object in one of the following ways:

  • $ObjectIdentifier - An object identifier is an opaque string provided by Amazon Cloud Directory. When creating objects, the system will provide you with the identifier of the created object. An object’s identifier is immutable and no two objects will ever share the same object identifier

  • /some/path - Identifies the object based on path

  • #SomeBatchReference - Identifies the object in a batch call

post.description: Returns a paginated list of all the outgoing TypedLinkSpecifier information for an object. It also supports filtering by typed link facet and identity attributes. For more information, see Typed Links.

TypedLinkSpecifiers.description: Returns a typed link specifier as output.

items.description: Contains all the information that is used to uniquely identify a typed link. The parameters discussed in this topic are used to uniquely specify the typed link being operated on. The AttachTypedLink API returns a typed link specifier while the DetachTypedLink API accepts one as input. Similarly, the ListIncomingTypedLinks and ListOutgoingTypedLinks API operations provide typed link specifiers as output. You can also construct a typed link specifier from scratch.

Selector.description:
A path selector supports easy selection of an object by the parent/child links leading to it from the directory root. Use the link names from each parent/child link to construct the path. Path selectors start with a slash (/) and link names are separated by slashes. For more information about paths, see Access Objects. You can identify an object in one of the following ways:

  • $ObjectIdentifier - An object identifier is an opaque string provided by Amazon Cloud Directory. When creating objects, the system will provide you with the identifier of the created object. An object’s identifier is immutable and no two objects will ever share the same object identifier

  • /some/path - Identifies the object based on path

  • #SomeBatchReference - Identifies the object in a batch call

Selector.description:
A path selector supports easy selection of an object by the parent/child links leading to it from the directory root. Use the link names from each parent/child link to construct the path. Path selectors start with a slash (/) and link names are separated by slashes. For more information about paths, see Access Objects. You can identify an object in one of the following ways:

  • $ObjectIdentifier - An object identifier is an opaque string provided by Amazon Cloud Directory. When creating objects, the system will provide you with the identifier of the created object. An object’s identifier is immutable and no two objects will ever share the same object identifier

  • /some/path - Identifies the object based on path

  • #SomeBatchReference - Identifies the object in a batch call

items.description: Contains all the information that is used to uniquely identify a typed link. The parameters discussed in this topic are used to uniquely specify the typed link being operated on. The AttachTypedLink API returns a typed link specifier while the DetachTypedLink API accepts one as input. Similarly, the ListIncomingTypedLinks and ListOutgoingTypedLinks API operations provide typed link specifiers as output. You can also construct a typed link specifier from scratch.

LookupPolicy.description: Lists all policies from the root of the Directory to the object specified. If there are no policies present, an empty list is returned. If policies are present, it returns ObjectIdentifier, policyId, and policyType. Paths that don't lead to the root from the target object are ignored. For more information, see Policies.

LookupPolicy.description: Lists all policies from the root of the Directory to the object specified. If there are no policies present, an empty list is returned. If policies are present, and if some objects don't have the policies attached, it returns the ObjectIdentifier for such objects.   • $ObjectIdentifier - An object identifier is an opaque string provided by Amazon Cloud Directory. When creating objects, the system will provide you with the identifier of the created object. An object’s identifier is immutable and no two objects will ever share the same object identifier

  • /some/path - Identifies the object based on path

  • #SomeBatchReference - Identifies the object in a batch call

LookupPolicy.description: Lists all policies from the root of the Directory to the object specified. If there are no policies present, an empty list is returned. If policies are present, and if some objects don't have the policies attached, it returns the ObjectIdentifier for such objects. If policies are present, it returns ObjectIdentifier, policyId, and policyType. Paths that don't lead to the root from the target object are ignored. For more information, see Policies.

ListIncomingTypedLinks.description: Returns a paginated list of all the incoming TypedLinkSpecifier information for an object. It also supports filtering by typed link facet and identity attributes. For more information, see Typed Links.

items.description: Contains all the information that is used to uniquely identify a typed link. The parameters discussed in this topic are used to uniquely specify the typed link being operated on. The AttachTypedLink API returns a typed link specifier while the DetachTypedLink API accepts one as input. Similarly, the ListIncomingTypedLinks and ListOutgoingTypedLinks API operations provide typed link specifiers as output. You can also construct a typed link specifier from scratch.

Selector.description:
A path selector supports easy selection of an object by the parent/child links leading to it from the directory root. Use the link names from each parent/child link to construct the path. Path selectors start with a slash (/) and link names are separated by slashes. For more information about paths, see Access Objects. You can identify an object in one of the following ways:

  • $ObjectIdentifier - An object identifier is an opaque string provided by Amazon Cloud Directory. When creating objects, the system will provide you with the identifier of the created object. An object’s identifier is immutable and no two objects will ever share the same object identifier

  • /some/path - Identifies the object based on path

  • #SomeBatchReference - Identifies the object in a batch call

LookupPolicy.description: Lists all policies from the root of the Directory to the object specified. If there are no policies present, an empty list is returned. If policies are present, and if some objects don't have the policies attached, it returns the ObjectIdentifier for such objects. If policies are present, it returns ObjectIdentifier, policyId, and policyType. Paths that don't lead to the root from the target object are ignored. For more information, see Policies.

  • $ObjectIdentifier - An object identifier is an opaque string provided by Amazon Cloud Directory. When creating objects, the system will provide you with the identifier of the created object. An object’s identifier is immutable and no two objects will ever share the same object identifier

  • /some/path - Identifies the object based on path

  • #SomeBatchReference - Identifies the object in a batch call

A path selector supports easy selection of an object by the parent/child links leading to it from the directory root. Use the link names from each parent/child link to construct the path. Path selectors start with a slash (/) and link names are separated by slashes. For more information about paths, see Access Objects. You can identify an object in one of the following ways:

  • $ObjectIdentifier - An object identifier is an opaque string provided by Amazon Cloud Directory. When creating objects, the system will provide you with the identifier of the created object. An object’s identifier is immutable and no two objects will ever share the same object identifier

  • /some/path - Identifies the object based on path

  • #SomeBatchReference - Identifies the object in a batch call

Selector.description:
A path selector supports easy selection of an object by the parent/child links leading to it from the directory root. Use the link names from each parent/child link to construct the path. Path selectors start with a slash (/) and link names are separated by slashes. For more information about paths, see Access Objects. You can identify an object in one of the following ways:

  • $ObjectIdentifier - An object identifier is an opaque string provided by Amazon Cloud Directory. When creating objects, the system will provide you with the identifier of the created object. An object’s identifier is immutable and no two objects will ever share the same object identifier

  • /some/path - Identifies the object based on path

  • #SomeBatchReference - Identifies the object in a batch call

ObjectType.description:
Specifies whether a given object created from this facet is of type node, leaf node, policy or index.

  • Node: Can have multiple children but one parent.

  • Leaf node: Cannot have children but can have multiple parents.

  • Policy: Allows you to store a policy document and policy type. For more information, see Policies.

  • Index: Can be created with the Index API.

IdentityAttributeOrder.description: The order of identity attributes for the facet, from most significant to least significant. The ability to filter typed links considers the order that the attributes are defined on the typed link facet. When providing ranges to typed link selection, any inexact ranges must be specified at the end. Any attributes that do not have a range specified are presumed to match the entire range. Filters are interpreted in the order of the attributes on the typed link facet, not the order in which they are supplied to any API calls. For more information about identity attributes, see Typed Links.

A path selector supports easy selection of an object by the parent/child links leading to it from the directory root. Use the link names from each parent/child link to construct the path. Path selectors start with a slash (/) and link names are separated by slashes. For more information about paths, see Access Objects. You can identify an object in one of the following ways:

  • $ObjectIdentifier - An object identifier is an opaque string provided by Amazon Cloud Directory. When creating objects, the system will provide you with the identifier of the created object. An object’s identifier is immutable and no two objects will ever share the same object identifier

  • /some/path - Identifies the object based on path

  • #SomeBatchReference - Identifies the object in a batch call

items.description: Contains the PolicyType, PolicyId, and the ObjectIdentifier to which it is attached. For more information, see Policies.

ObjectIdentifier.description: The ObjectIdentifier that is associated with PolicyAttachment.

PolicyType.description: The type of policy that can be associated with PolicyAttachment.

MinorVersion.description: The minor version under which the schema will be published. This parameter is recommended. Schemas have both a major and minor version associated with them.

Name.description: The new name under which the schema will be published. If this is not provided, the development schema is considered.

Version.description: The major version under which the schema will be published. Schemas have both a major and minor version associated with them.

PublishedSchemaArn.description: The ARN that is associated with the published schema. For more information, see arns.

Arn.description: The ARN of the schema to update.

ObjectReference.description: A reference to the object to remove the facet from.

Selector.description:
A path selector supports easy selection of an object by the parent/child links leading to it from the directory root. Use the link names from each parent/child link to construct the path. Path selectors start with a slash (/) and link names are separated by slashes. For more information about paths, see Access Objects. You can identify an object in one of the following ways:

  • $ObjectIdentifier - An object identifier is an opaque string provided by Amazon Cloud Directory. When creating objects, the system will provide you with the identifier of the created object. An object’s identifier is immutable and no two objects will ever share the same object identifier

  • /some/path - Identifies the object based on path

  • #SomeBatchReference - Identifies the object in a batch call

TypedLinkFacet.description: Defines the typed links structure and its attributes. To create a typed link facet, use the CreateTypedLinkFacet API.

Attributes.description: A set of key-value pairs associated with the typed link. Typed link attributes are used when you have data values that are related to the link itself, and not to one of the two objects being linked. Identity attributes also serve to distinguish the link from others of the same type between the same objects.

TypedLinkSpecifier.description: Contains all the information that is used to uniquely identify a typed link. The parameters discussed in this topic are used to uniquely specify the typed link being operated on. The AttachTypedLink API returns a typed link specifier while the DetachTypedLink API accepts one as input. Similarly, the ListIncomingTypedLinks and ListOutgoingTypedLinks API operations provide typed link specifiers as output. You can also construct a typed link specifier from scratch.

IdentityAttributeValues.description: Identifies the attribute value to update.

items.description: Identifies the attribute name and value for a typed link.

AttributeName.description: The attribute name of the typed link.

Value.description: The value for the typed link.

SourceObjectReference.description: Identifies the source object that the typed link will attach to.

Selector.description:
A path selector supports easy selection of an object by the parent/child links leading to it from the directory root. Use the link names from each parent/child link to construct the path. Path selectors start with a slash (/) and link names are separated by slashes. For more information about paths, see Access Objects. You can identify an object in one of the following ways:

  • $ObjectIdentifier - An object identifier is an opaque string provided by Amazon Cloud Directory. When creating objects, the system will provide you with the identifier of the created object. An object’s identifier is immutable and no two objects will ever share the same object identifier

  • /some/path - Identifies the object based on path

  • #SomeBatchReference - Identifies the object in a batch call

TargetObjectReference.description: Identifies the target object that the typed link will attach to.

IdentityAttributeOrder.description: The order of identity attributes for the facet, from most significant to least significant. The ability to filter typed links considers the order that the attributes are defined on the typed link facet. When providing ranges to a typed link selection, any inexact ranges must be specified at the end. Any attributes that do not have a range specified are presumed to match the entire range. Filters are interpreted in the order of the attributes on the typed link facet, not the order in which they are supplied to any API calls. For more information about identity attributes, see Typed Links.

Name.description: The unique name of the typed link facet.

DirectoryArn.description: The ARN for the directory to which the upgraded schema will be applied.

DryRun.description: Used for testing whether the major version schemas are backward compatible or not. If schema compatibility fails, an exception would be thrown else the call would succeed but no changes will be saved. This parameter is optional.

PublishedSchemaArn.description: The revision of the published schema to upgrade the directory to.

DirectoryArn.description: The ARN of the directory that is returned as part of the response.

UpgradedSchemaArn.description: The ARN of the upgraded schema that is returned as part of the response.

DevelopmentSchemaArn.description: The ARN of the development schema with the changes used for the upgrade.

DryRun.description: Used for testing whether the Development schema provided is backwards compatible, or not, with the publish schema provided by the user to be upgraded. If schema compatibility fails, an exception would be thrown else the call would succeed. This parameter is optional and defaults to false.

MinorVersion.description: Identifies the minor version of the published schema that will be created. This parameter is NOT optional.

PublishedSchemaArn.description: The ARN of the published schema to be upgraded.

UpgradedSchemaArn.description: The ARN of the upgraded schema that is returned as part of the response.

MaxResults.description: The maximum number of results to retrieve.

Name.description: The unique name of the typed link facet.
